subdisciplines.name: Biomechanics
subdisciplines.description: The study of mechanical properties of biological tissues, such as bones, muscles and organs, and the application of engineering principles to understand their function and behaviors.

subdisciplines.name: Bioinstrumentation
subdisciplines.description: The design, development, and application of instruments used to diagnose and treat medical conditions.

subdisciplines.name: Biomedical Imaging
subdisciplines.description: The development and application of technology to produce images of internal structures and functions of the body for medical diagnosis, treatment and research.

subdisciplines.name: Biomaterials
subdisciplines.description: The study of materials that interact with biological systems for medical and biological applications, such as implants, drug delivery devices and tissue engineering.

subdisciplines.name: Biomechanics
subdisciplines.description: The study of the mechanics of biological systems, including humans and other animals.

subdisciplines.name: Biosensors
subdisciplines.description: The design, development, and application of sensors that can detect biological substances or processes.

subdisciplines.name: Medical Imaging
subdisciplines.description: The use of technology to create visual representations of internal body structures, for diagnostic or therapeutic purposes.

subdisciplines.name: Computational Biology
subdisciplines.description: The development and application of computer models, algorithms and software to understand biological processes and systems, and to design new drugs and therapies.

subdisciplines.name: Rehabilitation Engineering
subdisciplines.description: The application of engineering principles and technology to develop devices and systems to assist individuals with disabilities in their daily activities.
